source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The zirconium tetrachloride was purified by dissolving it in a molten-salt bath, then pumping the resulting salt mixture into a vaporizer, where the tetrachloride was vaporized and then condensed in another vessel.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Filtered liquid sodium and solid zirconium tetrachloride were metered into a continuous reactor where $\mathbf { Z r C l } _ { 2 }$ and NaCl were formed at a temperature of about $2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( 3 9 2 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { F } )$ .

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The pots were then placed in floor furnaces and heated to several hundred degrees, at which point the second reduction reaction proceeded to reduce the $\mathbf { Z r C l } _ { 2 }$ to metallic zirconium, exothermically raising the temperature of the pot to a red heat.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: After several hours of soaking, the pots were removed from the furnace, allowed to cool, and then opened.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: A jackhammer was used to break the reaction mass and salt out of the pot, after which the mass was crushed to $6 \ \mathrm { m m } \ ( 0 . 2 5 \ \mathrm { i n } )$ size and leached with water.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: However, after leaching, the sponge still contained about $1 / _ { 2 } \%$ NaCl and some sodium; hence, it would not meet AEC specifications.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The sponge was compacted into an electrode and fed through an induction coil in an inert atmosphere, and the molten zirconium was allowed to drip on to a rotating disk.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: At first, "platelets" about I in. $( 2 . 5 4 \mathrm { c m } )$ in diameter were formed by this process, but these were difficult to compact into consumable electrodes for arc melting.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Finally, the melting rate was speeded up so that "chunklets" were formed, and these proved highly satisfactory.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: the major application of zirconium as a structural material in nuclear reactor cores demands that the hafnium content be reduced to below 100 ppm and, for some applications, below 50 ppm.

evidence_span: the thermal neutron absorption cross section of hafnium at 105 barns is almost 600 times as great as that of zirconium

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: the need to also produce a hafnium product with a zirconium content of $2 \%$ or less.

evidence_span: The aqueous zirconium raffinate is diluted to a zirconium content of about $_ { 1 2 \mathrm { ~ g ~ } }$ /litre (0.1 lb/gal)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk8

evidence_span: Both metal product streams are distilled to recover free nitric acid, and neutralized to precipitate the hydrates, which are then calcined to the oxides

evidence_span: The eutectic salt, which melts at $4 5 0 \mathrm { { \circ C } }$ $( 8 4 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ , is obtained when using bimetallic reductant containing 58.8 weight $\%$ sodium and 41.2 weight $\%$ magnesium

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk10
evidence_span: any metal mixture containing 24.9 to 74.2 weight $\%$ sodium brings the melting point of the resulting salts down below the melting point of magnesium, which is $6 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

evidence_span: The heat of reaction, when using sodium as a reductant for $\mathbf { Z r C l _ { 4 } }$ , is 124.6 kcal/mol versus 37.4 when using magnesium.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk10
evidence_span: The heat of reaction, when using sodium as a reductant for $\mathbf { Z r C l _ { 4 } }$ , is 124.6 kcal/mol versus 37.4 when using magnesium.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk10
evidence_span: concluded that the best quality of zirconium, with respect to oxygen content and hardness, was produced by reduction with a mixture of sodium and magnesium.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk10
evidence_span: Yields were also higher than when using either sodium or magnesium alone.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk10
evidence_span: Reduction reactions involving mixtures of sodium and magnesium can be conducted at lower temperatures than those made with magnesium alone

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk10
evidence_span: residual by-product salt mixtures can be more readily removed from the sponge by vacuum distillation than salts from either sodium- or magnesium-reduced sponge.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk10

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk10
evidence_span: The zirconium metal compact consists of a $1 5 . 2 – \mathsf { c m }$ -diameter (6 in.) cylinder of finely divided zirconium metal uniformly distributed in a matrix of salt and excess magnesium metal.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_004_chunk10
evidence_span: The compacts were vacuum-distilled before melting but still contained much higher residual salt levels than conventional Kroll process sponge
